parts.title: Part 1 - Introduction to Forms
parts.description: Learn the basics of HTML forms and how to create form elements. Discover the HTML skeleton shortcut and understand form structure with labels and inputs.
keyConcepts: Form attributes: type, placeholder, name, id, for

parts.title: Part 2 - Radio Buttons, Checkboxes, Select, and Textarea
parts.videoTitle: Radio Buttons, Checkboxes, Select, and Textarea
parts.description: Learn how to create radio buttons for multiple choice options in forms. Understand how to group radio buttons and connect labels properly.
keyConcepts: Grouping radio buttons with name attribute
Connecting labels with for and id
Textarea tag for longer text input

question1.text: How do you group radio buttons so only one can be selected?

question2.text: What is the difference between radio buttons and checkboxes?

options.text: Radio buttons allow multiple selections, checkboxes allow only one
Radio buttons allow only one selection, checkboxes allow multiple
Radio buttons are for text, checkboxes are for numbers

question3.text: Why do we connect a label to an input using 'for' and 'id'?

options.text: So clicking the label selects the input

parts.title: Part 3 - Styling Forms
parts.description: Learn how to style forms using CSS. Understand the difference between inline and block elements, and use div tags to structure form layout.
keyConcepts: Using div tags to group form elements

question1.text: What is the difference between inline and block elements?

options.text: Inline goes left-to-right, block takes full width
Block goes left-to-right, inline takes full width

question2.text: Why do we use <div> tags in forms?

options.text: To group elements and create structure

parts.description: Learn how to add background images to your forms using CSS and how to organize your styles in external CSS files. Discover free image resources and the background-image property.
keyConcepts: Using external stylesheets for shared CSS
